chapter.title: Noções Básicas
chapter.para: Apenas mostrar um "Hello World" não é o suficiente, não é? Você quer fazer mais que isso. Você quer receber alguma entrada, manipulá-la e obter uma saída. Em Python, podemos fazer isso usando constantes e variáveis.

section.title: Constantes Literais
section.para: Um exemplo de constante literal é um número como 5, 1.23, 9.25e-3 ou um string como 'This is a string' or "It's a string!". São chamados de literais porque eles são literais, ou seja, você usa seus valores literalmente. O número 2 sempre representa a si próprio e nada mais. Ele é uma constante porque seu valor não pode ser modificado. Dessa forma, todos esses valores são considerados constantes literais.

section.title: Números
section.para: Os números em Python podem ser de quatro tipos: inteiros, inteiros longos, números de ponto flutuante e números complexos.

listitem.para: Um exemplo de inteiro é o número 2, que não possui parte fracionária.
Inteiros longos também não possuem parte fracionária, porém podem assumir valores maiores que os inteiros comuns.
Exemplos de números de ponto flutuante são 3.23 e 52.3E-4. A notação E indica potências de 10. Neste caso, 52.3E-4 significa 52.3 * 10-4.
Exemplos de números complexos são (-5+4j) e (2.3 - 4.6j)

section.title: Strings
section.para: Uma string é uma seqüência de caracteres. Strings são basicamente um punhado de palavras.
Eu posso quase garantir que você usará strings em quase todos os programas em Python que você escrever. Então, preste atenção à parte seguinte. Aqui está como se usa strings em Python:

listitem.para: Você pode definir strings usando aspas simples, como em 'Cite-me aqui'. Todos os espaços em branco - isto é, espaços e tabs - são preservados da maneira em que estão.
Strings em aspas duplas funcionam exatamente da mesma maneira que strings em aspas simples. Um exemplo é "Qual é o seu nome?"
Você pode especificar strings em múltiplas linhas usando aspas triplas. É possível usar aspas simples (apóstrofos) ou aspas duplas livremente dentro das aspas triplas. Um exemplo é
listitem.programlisting: '''Esta é uma string em múltiplas linhas. Esta é a primeira linha. Esta é a segunda linha. "Qual é o seu nome?", perguntei. Ele disse "Bond, James Bond." '''

listitem.para: Suponha que você tem uma string que contém uma aspas simples ('). Como você a definiria? Por exemplo, na string Quero um copo d'água. Você não pode definir 'Quero um copo d'água' pois o Python ficaria confuso para saber onde a string começa e termina. Então, você tem que deixar claro para o Python que esta aspas simples não indica o final da string. Isto pode ser feito com a ajuda do que chamamos de seqüência de escape. Devemos escrever a aspas simples como \' (note a barra invertida). Desse modo, você pode especificar a string como 'Quero um copo d\'água'.

Uma outra maneira de definir esta string específica seria "Quero um copo d'água", isto é, usando aspas duplas. De maneira similar, você deve usar uma sequência de escape para mostrar uma aspa dupla dentro de uma string definida por aspas duplas. Do mesmo modo, a própria barra invertida é indicada pela seqüência de escape \\.

E se você quisesse definir uma string de duas linhas? Uma maneira é usar uma string definida por aspas triplas, conforme mostrado acima. Outra maneira seia usar uma seqüência de escape para o caracter que indica uma nova linha - \n. Um exemplo seria Esta é a primeira linha\nEsta é a segunda linha. Uma outra seqüencia de escape útil é o caracter tab - \t. Existem várias outras seqüências de escape, mas mencionei aqui apenas as mais úteis.
Vale frisar que, numa string, uma única barra invertida ao final de uma linha indica que a string continua na próxima linha, sem que nenhuma nova linha seja adicionada. Por exemplo:
listitem.programlisting: "Esta é a primeira frase.\ Esta é a segunda frase."
listitem.para: é equivalente a "Esta é a primeira frase. Esta é a segunda frase."

If you need to specify some strings where no special processing such as escape sequences are handled, then what you need is to specify a raw string by prefixing r or R to the string. An example is r"Newlines are indicated by \n".

Unicode is a standard way of writing international text. If you want to write text in your native language such as Hindi or Arabic, then you need to have a Unicode-enabled text editor. Similarly, Python allows you to handle Unicode text - all you need to do is prefix u or U. For example, u"This is a Unicode string.".
Remember to use Unicode strings when you are dealing with text files, especially when you know that the file will contain text written in languages other than English.

This means that once you have created a string, you cannot change it. Although this might seem like a bad thing, it really isn't. We will see why this is not a limitation in the various programs that we see later on.
If you place two string literals side by side, they are automatically concatenated by Python. For example, 'What\'s' 'your name?' is automatically converted in to "What's your name?".

note.title: Note for C/C++ Programmers
note.para: There is no separate char data type in Python. There is no real need for it and I am sure you won't miss it.

note.title: Note for Perl/PHP Programmers
note.para: Remember that single-quoted strings and double-quoted strings are the same - they do not differ in any way.

note.title: Note for Regular Expression Users
note.para: Always use raw strings when dealing with regular expressions. Otherwise, a lot of backwhacking may be required. For example, backreferences can be referred to as '\\1' or r'\1'.

section.title: Variables
section.para: Using just literal constants can soon become boring - we need some way of storing any information and manipulate them as well. This is where variables come into the picture. Variables are exactly what they mean - their value can vary i.e. you can store anything using a variable. Variables are just parts of your computer's memory where you store some information. Unlike literal constants, you need some method of accessing these variables and hence you give them names.

section.title: Identifier Naming
section.para: Variables are examples of identifiers. Identifiers are names given to identify something. There are some rules you have to follow for naming identifiers:

listitem.para: The first character of the identifier must be a letter of the alphabet (upper or lowercase) or an underscore ('_').
The rest of the identifier name can consist of letters (upper or lowercase), underscores ('_') or digits (0-9).
Identifier names are case-sensitive. For example, myname and myName are not the same. Note the lowercase n in the former and the uppercase N in te latter.
Examples of valid identifier names are i, __my_name, name_23 and a1b2_c3.
Examples of invalid identifier names are 2things, this is spaced out and my-name.

section.title: Data Types
section.para: Variables can hold values of different types called data types. The basic types are numbers and strings, which we have already discussed. In later chapters, we will see how to create our own types using classes.

section.title: Objects
section.para: Remember, Python refers to anything used in a program as an object. This is meant in the generic sense. Instead of saying 'the something', we say 'the object'.

note.title: Note for Object Oriented Programming users
note.para: Python is strongly object-oriented in the sense that everything is an object including numbers, strings and even functions.

section.para: We will now see how to use variables along with literal constants. Save the following example and run the program.

note.title: How to write Python programs
note.para: Henceforth, the standard procedure to save and run a Python program is as follows:

step.para: Enter the program code given in the example.
Save it as a file with the filename mentioned in the comment. I follow the convention of having all Python programs saved with the extension .py.
Run the interpreter with the command python program.py or use IDLE to run the programs. You can also use the executable method as explained earlier.

example.title: Using Variables and Literal constants
example.programlisting:
# Filename : var.py
i = 5 print i i = i + 1 print i
s = '''This is a multi-line string. This is the second line.''' print s

section.title: Output
section.screen: $ python var.py 5 6 This is a multi-line string. This is the second line.

section.title: How It Works
section.para: Here's how this program works. First, we assign the literal constant value 5 to the variable i using the assignment operator (=). This line is called a statement because it states that something should be done and in this case, we connect the variable name i to the value 5. Next, we print the value of i using the print statement which, unsurprisingly, just prints the value of the variable to the screen.
The we add 1 to the value stored in i and store it back. We then print it and expectedly, we get the value 6.
Similarly, we assign the literal string to the variable s and then print it.

note.title: Note for C/C++ Programmers
note.para: Variables are used by just assigning them a value. No declaration or data type definition is needed/used.

section.title: Logical and Physical Lines
section.para: A physical line is what you see when you write the program. A logical line is what Python sees as a single statement. Python implicitly assumes that each physical line corresponds to a logical line.
An example of a logical line is a statement like print 'Hello World' - if this was on a line by itself (as you see it in an editor), then this also corresponds to a physical line.
Implicitly, Python encourages the use of a single statement per line which makes code more readable.

However, I strongly recommend that you stick to writing a single logical line in a single physical line only. Use more than one physical line for a single logical line only if the logical line is really long. The idea is to avoid the semicolon as far as possible since it leads to more readable code. In fact, I have never used or even seen a semicolon in a Python program.
An example of writing a logical line spanning many physical lines follows. This is referred to as explicit line joining.
section.programlisting: s = 'This is a string. \ This continues the string.' print s
section.para: This gives the output:
section.screen: This is a string. This continues the string.

Sometimes, there is an implicit assumption where you don't need to use a backslash. This is the case where the logical line uses parentheses, square brackets or curly braces. This is is called implicit line joining. You can see this in action when we write programs using lists in later chapters.

section.title: Indentation
section.para: Whitespace is important in Python. Actually, whitespace at the beginning of the line is important. This is called indentation. Leading whitespace (spaces and tabs) at the beginning of the logical line is used to determine the indentation level of the logical line, which in turn is used to determine the grouping of statements.
This means that statements which go together must have the same indentation. Each such set of statements is called a block. We will see examples of how blocks are important in later chapters.
One thing you should remember is how wrong indentation can give rise to errors. For example:
section.programlisting: i = 5 print 'Value is', i # Error! Notice a single space at the start of the line print 'I repeat, the value is', i
section.para: When you run this, you get the following error:
section.screen: File "whitespace.py", line 4 print 'Value is', i # Error! Notice a single space at the start of the line ^ SyntaxError: invalid syntax
section.para: Notice that there is a single space at the beginning of the second line. The error indicated by Python tells us that the syntax of the program is invalid i.e. the program was not properly written. What this means to you is that you cannot arbitrarily start new blocks of statements (except for the main block which you have been using all along, of course). Cases where you can use new blocks will be detailed in later chapters such as the control flow chapter.

important.title: How to indent
important.para: Do not use a mixture of tabs and spaces for the indentation as it does not work across different platforms properly. I strongly recommend that you use a single tab or two or four spaces for each indentation level.
Choose any of these three indentation styles. More importantly, choose one and use it consistently i.e. use that indentation style only.

section.title: Summary
section.para: Now that we have gone through many nitty-gritty details, we can move on to more interesting stuff such as control flow statements. Be sure to become comfortable with what you have read in this chapter.
